samples.question: Now, how can you do that?
samples.transcript: Like you are taking your test in, March. You have enough time to memorize new vocabulary, work on new publications and widen your vocabulary range. But there is a strategy that can help you even use your knowledge, like the knowledge you have right now to get a higher score. And that is about faking your answer. This is what I was talking about in the previous criteria. This technique now can help you a lot to have a better brainstorming and use A better range of vocabulary This way you will have a better fluency be aware of hesitations and use better words and collocations Like whatever you know you already know Faking your answer means to lie. In IELTS speaking, you can simply lie. You can pretend. Because the examiner does not really know what is going on in your mind, or what you really think, or if this is really your opinion on something. So you can simply lie about it. And as long as your answer is related to the question and it makes sense, you are good to go. For example, if I ask you to describe your house, you do not know how to do that, but you do know how to describe somebody else's house. Then describe your house as if you are talking about your house.

samples.question: Who taught you how to cook?

samples.question: So why do parents let their children play puzzles?
samples.transcript: I think the biggest reason for this is that puzzles are great learning tools and they do wonders for children's intellectual development. You know, puzzles are mentally stimulating activities which help people strengthen their mind. And while children and when children play them they are able to improve their levels of concentration and develop other skills such as logical thinking and problem solving What kinds of puzzles improve people intelligence Well, I would say that all types of puzzles, helped one enhance their intellect, intelligence one way or another. You know, puzzles like Chicksaw, Sotoku, and Rubik's Cube allow people to work on their concentration and problem-solving skills and improve cognition. Meanwhile, people can have wider vocabulary, vocabulary resources, through other puzzles like crossword.

samples.question: What we want to do is show that you have a wider range of vocabulary.
samples.transcript: So you could say something like, well, I do not mind surprises. I suppose it depends on the situation. I like to plan some things, but if my friend threw me an impromptu party, impromptu means surprise or not planned. So you will see the word on the screen there, impromptu. You could also use kind of an idiomatic expression such as out of the blue. So if my friend turned up out of the blue, I would really like that. So out of the blue means unexpectedly or as a surprise. So there are different ways you could use language to show up to paraphrase. And I think Stephen is just lacking that here. even though he is got a good range of vocabulary and really easy to understand, there is a couple of points that I think that if he were to sit the test again in the future, he may just want to consider using a little bit more variety in his language. Great.

samples.question: And in previous videos when we have had native speakers, some people have asked, well why do you have a native speaker?
samples.transcript: There are a couple of reasons actually. The first reason is that sometimes native speakers do have to take the test Because maybe they studied abroad in a country where English is not the first language. And when they return to their country, maybe they are doctors or dentists, they have to take the IELTS test. So that is one reason. The second reason that we use native speakers is because we want to teach you lots of great features of language, whether that is grammar, vocabulary, or pronunciation. You can learn many things and you can learn ideas from native speakers. So let, without further ado, let us have a look at Romy from Australia. let us go. Okay, I hope you are ready. I am just getting prepared and Romy is a university student and she is interested in rowing. we are going to hear about her hobbies and a little bit about her daily routine. So, we should start by pressing play. Hello and welcome to this practice exam conducted by IELTS Daily. My name is Maddy and I am your practice IELTS speaking examiner. The questions in this test are designed to simulate the IELTS speaking test. So let us start.

samples.question: Is there a good way to give constructive feedback to someone about something?
samples.transcript: Yes, I definitely think there is and this is something that I have learned about in one of the courses I am studying at uni too, which was about sports coaching. So how we can give constructive feedback and help our students to learn to learn from their mistakes. And I think it is really important when giving constructive feedback to say something positive first, to make sure you are not too negative and that you do not have a negative tone to your voice, that you are happy. and that you are just generally trying to help them. You want to give off the vibe that you are just trying to help them and not that you are trying to put them down. I think it is one of the worst things when someone's telling you something and you know they are just trying to let you down and trying to make you feel bad about yourself. So I always try and start with something positive and then say, how about we try this or how about next time you do this? I think always phrasing it as a question is also a more sensitive way to approach the topic. In pronunciation there is a feature of, of language which is called the weak form. The weak form is when we do not put the stress on the, the word. And if you go back and listen to Romy, she very often uses the weak form of the sound to, to see, to do. We do not say to see or to do, we say to see, to do. And she uses this weak form with this sound called the schwa, the a sound, the t-t-t, to see, to do, to watch, to sing. And you will notice that she uses the weak form really well.

It calms me down. It makes me relaxed. So to calm somebody down. It calmed me down by speaking to her. samples.question: What type of shoes do you usually wear?
samples.transcript: I wear sandals because you don need socks for sandals and it easier to wear and it comfortable and also I wear sneakers as well because I do a lot of sports like fencing badminton so I need sneakers for that we are on to a new topic now which is shoes. You may get this topic in your test so be prepared for a topic like this. Now in her answer she said I wear sandals because you do not need socks for sandals and that is a compound sentence but she is explaining the reason why, Which is wonderful. I really like that. And then she starts, these little errors start slipping through. She said, and it is easy, easier to wear and it is comfortable. And the problem here is that she is referring to the wrong type of noun. She is referring to a singular noun. And actually she is talking about sandals. And the correct form, the correct pronoun there should be they are easier to wear and they are, they are more comfortable. And so she is mixing up the singulars and plurals there. But then she redeemed herself and she says, because I do a lot of sport. Notice there how she is changed the because to because. Because I do a lot of sport and lots of people think that the IELTS speaking test is a formal test and that you cannot contract words, you cannot shorten words. Well that is actually a myth and the word cause is absolutely appropriate and acceptable in the test. So I encourage you, if you can use it naturally, then definitely think about that. Then she is used words like sneakers. I, I also, she said also I wear sneakers as well. She is actually repeating two cohesive devices there. She is using also and as well together. Probably one of them would be redundant and she said like fencing and badminton. Good start. I am just a little bit concerned about these little grammar slips that are coming through.

samples.question: How have you studied English and what tips or advice would you give to other students studying English and preparing for IELTS?
samples.transcript: Well, you know, here in the Philippines, as I said before, English is part of our curriculum. And we study from kindergarten until primary school, high school. So we really need to study English. But the thing is, we just do not have the environment to talk to someone in English. we have been hearing a lot of English advertisements like on TV, but the thing is we just do not have the environment or atmosphere to speak English. So what I did was like, I just kept on speaking. Yeah. Like I, I basically immersed myself in English language. I guess that that is very important. And, if it is possible to have a speaking partner, that would be better. But if you do not have a speaking partner, just simply talk to yourself. Like, I mean, when you are just doing some simple things in life, like your daily routine. samples.question: Ví dụ như là mô tả một một cái quốc gia mà mình muốn ghé thăm, đúng không?
samples.transcript: Thì trong trường hợp này thì mình sẽ cần phải thay đổi một chút. Mình không thể nói quốc gia đó là cái library được. Thì anh sẽ lại hướng dẫn cách xử lý nó ở phần sau của video nhé. Đó thì đấy là cách mình chuẩn bị sẵn một số những cái model subjects cho từng chủ đề people, activity, Things, experience, and place. Thì khi được hỏi về một chủ đề, mình cứ lôi cái model của mình ra để mà nói thôi. Mình không mất thời gian nghĩ về một chủ đề nào đó nữa. Nhưng đó mới chỉ là nghĩ ra được cái model mà mình sẽ nói đến thôi. Và giới thiệu qua về nó thôi. Còn làm sao để nghĩ sẵn ra tiếp những cái phần mở rộng để nói cho nó. Cho đủ 2 phút của cái phần Speaking Part 2. Thì bây giờ mình sẽ đi vào cái phần này nhé. Kết hợp các model subjects của mình để cho ra một câu chuyện hoàn chỉnh. Khi các em chuẩn bị sẵn những cái model subjects cho từng chủ đề. Thì thực chất các em đã vẽ sẵn ra hàng chục câu chuyện dài rồi. Một lỗi mà nhiều bạn hay mắc phải là chỉ nói đúng về cái chủ đề mà câu hỏi nó đang hỏi thôi. Và không đề cập bất kỳ một cái gì đến các chủ đề khác vì nghĩ rằng nó không liên quan. Nhưng điều này thì lại không đúng. Một câu chuyện thì luôn luôn có nhiều khía cạnh, nó sẽ có những nhân vật trong đó, nó có một hoạt động, nó có một vật dụng nào đó, một trải nghiệm và có cả địa điểm. Khi mình kết hợp chúng lại với nhau thì chúng nó sẽ trở thành một câu chuyện với nhiều khía cạnh. Lấy một ví dụ nhé. Các bạn có thể nói về người bạn Bean này của mình và kể rằng bọn anh thường chơi tennis cùng nhau này. Có thể thêm một câu chuyện là cái iPhone của anh bị hỏng khi mà chơi tennis vào tuần trước. Hay là Bean luôn luôn đến dự tiệc sinh nhật của con gái của anh hàng năm. Và Bean là một chủ, một cái thư viện rộng lớn.

samples.question: What kind of food do you like?
samples.transcript: To be honest, I am a picky eater, so I do not really have a favorite food. But I guess that if I had to choose one, then I would go for something like pizza. I just love all that cheese and tomato sauce. Nên là ở part 3 này, các em nên trả lời dài lên một chút. Tất nhiên là đủ dài thôi, chứ không phải là dài trắng là lại hải ta. Khoảng 4 đến 6 câu thôi. Đừng lo bị ngắt nhá. Khi bị ngắt, tức là giám khảo đang quản lý thời gian để hoàn thành đủ tối thiểu lượng câu hỏi phải hỏi part 3 thôi. Thế thì khi các em trả lời đủ dài, các em sẽ đang kéo dài phần trả lời của mình ra. Và lượng câu hỏi ở đằng sau đang chờ các em nó sẽ bị ít lại. Vì họ chỉ có 5 phút vừa hỏi vừa trả lời thôi mà. Tức là các em sẽ bị hỏi ít câu hơn và những cái câu khó hơn đằng sau ấy người ta sẽ không còn thời gian để hỏi mình nữa. Như thế là mình vẫn chơi đúng luật câu trả lời của mình không hề ngắn, mà cũng không hề dài dòng, mà lại không bị hỏi các câu hỏi khó đằng sau.

samples.question: How often do you eat out?
samples.transcript: Before we continue, I have created something very special for you. it is called the Fluent Speakers Breakthrough Checklist. And it shows you exactly how to move from band 6.5 to band 7 or above in four simple steps. This is the same direct answer method that helped this student go from 6.5 scores to success by fixing one strategic weakness at a time. I put everything that I know about this into this free checklist and you can download it in the description in seconds. Just go to the description, click the link below and you can download it right away for free. Three, two years ago, I would really go out at least three times a week with my friends. But right now, having the thought of healthy living and thinking more about my future, my investments, my savings, and all of that, I barely eat out. And occasionally, when there is a birthday, or when I feel like treating myself like I have done a good job at work, probably, yeah, that is the only time I would eat out.

samples.question: So fluency again is can you speak without much effort, without many audible pauses, can you speak at a normal pace?
samples.transcript: You have no problem with that. that is probably your biggest strength. And this is what I often find with Filipinos is their fluency is great because you guys speak English so much, fluency, and especially if you work in an English speaking environment, your fluency is very, very good.
samples.transcript_original: You have no problem with that. That's probably your biggest strength. And this is what I often find with Filipinos is their fluency is great because you guys speak English so much, um, fluency, and especially if you work in an English speaking environment, your fluency is very, very good.

samples.question: And then you, why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you, it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking, let us call it Filipino English for many, many years. And no one has ever said that is an error. But when you do the IELTS test, again, you are moving to an English speaking country. They will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of. So for example, staff was not that much helpful. It should have been the staff were not very helpful. Or every household in Philippines, there is really gardens. Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. Yeah. there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subject verb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for example, let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get about six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences, you would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small, just small little errors in most sentences, so you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students, and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent. But this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall, you would be in and around 6.5 or 7 overall. Now for most people, 7 is, is, great for, from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My, advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before, a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you, you do not know you have, you are even making them. It does not affect communication. So it is not a huge issue. It just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

samples.question: When the examiner asks Anthony, when is the last time you went shopping there?
samples.transcript: Anthony has difficulty explaining that he went shopping there about a week ago. This sentence is way too simple for band five or higher. He should have immediately connected with an explanation because my family was running low on food and we needed to restock the fridge so we could cook at home and save money that way. This kind of compound complex sentence would be the way to earn those high scores. Giving a simple answer as Anthony did would be a band four. Poor grammar and unfinished sentences continue to degrade Anthony's overall score for the speaking section. In order to avoid this, a couple of tricks that you can follow are to reflect the grammar of the questions. When asked how have grocery stores changed in the past few decades, you should respond by using the question and using the grammar, stating they have changed a lot in the last 10 to 20 years. Nowadays, most grocery stores offer a wide range of foods from around the world. By using the question to start your response, you are able to build momentum and fluency. But of course, this takes practice. Pay attention to building your vocabulary using connective words as often as possible and paying attention to good strategy, answering, explaining, and giving examples. Follow these tips and you will for sure get into those band 7, 8, and even 9 levels on your next IELTS exam.

samples.question: Why do people want to learn a foreign language?
samples.transcript: I think that depends a bit on the person, but probably the most common motivation is to be able to talk to people from other countries who have a different cultural background, who speak a different language. Because I think that being able to speak a foreign language really opens doors to you. Because even if you go to a different country, if you do not speak the language, people are less willing to share information with you. And if you do approach the people in their own language, they are usually very glad to help you out and to explain more. So what is the best way to learn a foreign language Through reading through writing or through speaking Yeah For me personally it listening and speaking and just a bit of kind of trial and error but I do think that depends a lot on the person and their personality because I think an introvert person would probably rather study at home and read and write and study maybe the grammar rather than approach a different person directly And, practice their speaking skills.

samples.question: Which is a none other than English language.
samples.transcript: After completing my senior secondary education. I made my mind. I will learn the foreign language as I am planning to go abroad for my higher education. So my parents suggested me to join the nearby institute Reynolds Institute. I enjoy it and I burn the midnight oil in order to learn the foreign language. Apart from it, I watched many web series with subtitles in order to improve my understanding. If I talk about the difficulties, what type of difficulties I faced when I learned this language. In the beginning days I face lots of problems in the grammar rules and regulations and the vocabulary in the pronunciation but after doing lots of hard work I became excel and I did my best in order to improve my foreign language apart from it if I talk about the benefits what type of benefits I received after learning it like as I build my confidence as well as I can easily communicate with the people most of my friends are from the foreign country. So now I have a good hand in the English. So I can easily communicate with them with confidence. Apart from this I can also it also opens different types of doors like I can get a great career opportunities and I can also do the job in an international company. So in the last I would like to say that I felt satisfied after learning this foreign language. that is good. wonderful.

samples.question: [Transcript chunk 7]
samples.transcript: Very clear and it is easy to understand her for these reasons yumi could very well get a perfect score now here are some points to remember when you are doing the computer-based video chat version of the ielts exam follow these tips and you will get a higher score when doing the computer-based video chat version of the out speaking interview firstly it is important to position yourself comfortably in your chair and make sure that your headset and microphone are also comfortable now when you are speaking through a computer camera and microphone these act as filters so you need to be melodramatic this means that you want to emphasize about 10 more than usual in this way you will seem natural to the examiner also do not forget to use facial gestures smile smiling gives you confidence nod when the examiner asks you a question this shows acknowledgement of course in the video chat you cannot really use hand gestures too much because only the upper torso and head are visible so facial features become more important next blame the equipment if you miss a question or if you do not catch a question the first time you can get away with blaming the equipment once maybe twice do not do it often you can say I am sorry i could not quite hear you there can you please repeat that or you can say I am sorry that was not too clear maybe something's up with my headset can you please repeat that again once or twice you can do this and the examiner will repeat the questions however it might get suspicious if you do it more as well when you are doing the computer-based exam pay attention to looking into the camera rather than just at the screen this will give the feeling of eye.

samples.question: Are you using nice colorful descriptive words to basically paint a picture in the mind of your listener?
samples.transcript: That is really important. try to paint a clear well ststructured not a confusing but a well ststructured picture in your listener's mind using adjectives, adverbs and different kinds of sensory language. language that talks about the senses, how something feels, how something smells, how something tastes, how something looks, and how something sounds. Of course, use compound complex language. If you want to get a score over six, you cannot just use simple sentences. You have to join the sentences with conjunctions like and, nor, but, for, so, therefore, since, when, if, however, so on. So, review your conjunctions if you are not sure. And of course, use adjective clauses. Adjective clauses are a big part of the descriptive language. Now these three elements are related to each other. So when your language is complex, it also becomes more coherent. when your language is more natural again it is more coherent. when it is more complex it is more natural. So that is why you see these circles joined because complexity, coherence and natural language they each depend on each other. So as you improve one area, you improve the other areas. So work on each area individually and then combine them. So again, as I mentioned with this candidate, coherence is quite high. She gives very complete, clear answers, does not go off topic. she uses quite a bit of complex language. go back, review the interview again, pay attention to how descriptive her language is when she talks about part two. pay attention to how well she joins her sentences in all three parts with conjunctions and use of adjective clauses. The only element that is dropping her mark from being even higher, an eight or an 8.5, is some elements of the natural language. Sometimes it is a little bit unclear, a little bit difficult to hear what she is trying to say, but otherwise overall a very good interview. Definitely a 7 to 7.5 on the IELTS. go back again, watch the interview again, watch for these elements, watch how she uses these elements effectively, and then practice that at home. samples.question: Are you ready?
samples.transcript: Let us jump straight into part one of the speaking test. In part one, the examiner will begin by introducing themselves, then asking you to state your name and show your identification. Then, they will ask you three sets of questions about familiar topics. The first set usually asks you general questions about yourself, such as your work or study, your home, or the place where you live. The second and third sets are personal questions about familiar topics like the food you like, your hobbies, people you spend time with, and so on. you will get up to 12 questions in this part, and it is important to know how to answer them well in the time given. But do not worry, today you will only get four part one questions. Here are my tips for part one. First, give extended answers. As a general rule, I would say try to talk for around 20 seconds for each answer. that is the equivalent of about two to three written sentences. Try to add more information to your response, such as giving an example or a reason to explain your answer. Also, make sure your answers have complete sentences. do not just give single word answers. Finally, there are no right or wrong answers to the questions, but what you say should answer the question. Now, it is time for you to try part one. I am going to ask you one set of questions, and you will have 20 seconds to answer each. And to get the most out of today's practice test, I recommend you record your answers so you can go back and check how you went.

samples.question: And why I enjoyed it?
samples.transcript: Well, I had not seen Alex in 3 years, so it was a chance to reconnect and reminisce. Notice I am noting some strong vocab here. And I also enjoyed it because it showed our friendship is still strong. And now I will give my full response. Listen for my use of vocabulary and grammar structures, how I develop the topic and link my ideas and my pronunciation. I am going to talk about a time when I really enjoyed sharing a meal with a friend. It happened about a year ago when I met up with my old friend, Alex. we would been close in university, but after graduating, life got busy and we lost touch. In fact, it had been almost 3 years since we would last seen each other. So, we decided to catch up over dinner. We chose a cozy Chinese restaurant in the city that specialized in hot pot. It was a great choice because hot pot is such a social meal. You sit around a steaming pot cooking your own food and it naturally creates conversation. The atmosphere in the restaurant was warm and lively with the sound of bubbling broth and people chatting all around us. We ordered a vegetarian hot pot which was perfect because Alex is vegetarian. There was a huge variety of fresh ingredients, mushrooms, tofu, leafy greens, and noodles. I remember the spicy broth being absolutely delicious, and we kept adding more ingredients as we talked. The whole experience felt interactive, which made the meal even more enjoyable.

samples.question: [Transcript chunk 6]
samples.transcript: You do not go off-topic sometimes students hear that you should just keep talking until the examiner stops you this is not necessarily a good idea if you keep talking and suddenly you are talking about the moon and the stars and everything in between that is going to be really off topic and you are going to decrease your score so if you feel that you have answered the specific question completely and exactly then just stop wait for the next question always try to why question a lot of especially apart one questions here if you go back and look at this interview again you will notice that the candidate when she is talking about health when she is giving the responses she often gives the reason for her responses so why she exercises why she does not exercise and so forth your answers must be complete just like hers that is one of the points that is really pushing her score quite high is that her communication for the most part is quite clear it is very accurate and it is very complete so when you do the same for sure you will also get scores above 6 now another part of the speaking interview that the markers are looking for is how natural is your language so when they look at the naturality they try to see if your pronunciation is clear enough that words and sentences are not confusing for an English speaker again it does not have to be perfect sounding English it does not have to be perfect sounding English pronunciation there are lots of different English accents around the world but it does have to be clear enough that the listener is not confused by what is being said now in this case with the candidate there are some slight difficulties with pronunciation on some of the.

samples.question: [Transcript chunk 3]
samples.transcript: Course practice is key you can do this in our live classes in addition having good strategy is important rather than repeating information it is a good idea to think about explanations and examples as soon as you feel yourself getting stuck for ideas or vocabulary use the word because or consequently therefore and give a reason for your ideas in addition to fluency Anthony makes numerous mistakes with grammar and pronunciation when he says the phrase when I am out of hiking instead of saying when I am out for a hike or when he says currently working strong or sounds which would be much smoother in English currently working you must make sure to work on all of the different features of speech for your upcoming IELTS exam although pronunciation is not extremely important you do want to approximate some form of native English it does not matter if it is British or American just choose one and copy it as closely as possible you can do this by listening to your favorite TV actors actresses or podcasts and just repeating sentences if it feels a bit awkward you are on the right track another way to master introducing yourself pronunciation and grammar is by practicing with a native English speaking tutor you can do just that with cambly a world-class app that lets you connect with the tutor from the US Canada or the UK anywhere anytime and you can use this very special code 60 AE help by clicking the link in the video description to speak with a cambly tutor 10 minutes for free and get a 60 discount off 12 month plans but hurry up because this is only available for the first 100 people I have tried cambly and found it to be amazing for increasing vocabulary.

samples.transcript: Hi and welcome to a E helps IELTS test preparation videos in this video you will see a native Canadian English speaker who scores about an 8.5 for lots more help with the academic IELTS for different parts of the exam as well as the speaking section please visit us there and join the full course ok so just before we look at the speaking interview let us quickly discuss what you need to remember when you are thinking about your score for the speaking section of the IELTS so basically there will be 3 different factors that the markers of the IELTS will be looking at when they are judging your speaking interview the first point is natural speech so natural speech means how similar is your speaking to a native speakers so this includes pronunciation this includes your intonation so you are up and down in your sentences your enunciation so how well do you project your words of course your use of natural fillers like and use of slangs like want to Ghana use of idioms and of course self correction if you make a mistake do you stop and say oh sorry what I meant to say was or do you just simply correct yourself this is all part of natural speaking the second factor that they will be looking at very closely is coherence so this means do you answer the questions accurately do you stay on topic and do you give a complete and clear answer is it easy to understand what you are trying to save do not go off-topic do not just keep talking about anything and everything until the examiner stops you because you will lose scores when you have finished answering a question just thought the examiner will ask you the next one so it is important to be.

samples.question: However, my experience in the recent test went quite smoothly, so I made this video to share it with you.
samples.transcript: Let us watch together! When taking the IELTS Speaking test via Zoom, first, we 'll be called into a small room by the coordinator, similar to when you take the IELTS FaceTime test. there is already a laptop connected to the screen. Once connected, you can sit back and relax. let us start the test! So now they will ask me if I heard clearly, and you can adjust the volume in the lower part of the microphone I am wearing. I can increase or decrease the volume if I can hear clearly or feel it is too loud. The special thing is that when speaking, during the scene I just experienced in January, I still remember wearing a mask. Everyone else was saying, "Why, it is an online exam?" it is true that I did not see the person watching in person, and I still wore a mask. The reason I received was that this is for safety reasons. The microphone used during the exam is shared among the candidates, so you should wear a mask to protect yourself and those around you. Before entering the exam room, the staff reminded me that if, during the exam, for any reason, I could not hear the answer clearly, or I could andt hear a word clearly, I could ask again. I see that they repeat the questions for me, and this will not completely affect my score. Yeah, I am pretty reassured about that. Next, there will always be people standing outside, and if there is any problem, I just have to knock on the door and they 'll come in to help me during the Speaking section of the exam. So, Maximark will ask me directly as usual. But others will share their screens via a mouth-reading app, and that makes it quite clear to read. that is all; everything goes very normally. My speaking will be automatically recorded on the exam board's system, so you do not have to press any buttons or anything during the exam. You just have to do what you need to do to speak. And after you have finished your practice, you just stand there and leave. I spat it out, stood up, and went outside. Then I was in charge. The coordinator reminded me to check if my exam file was okay after about 3 to 5 minutes. If it was okay, I would proceed to hand it over to her, and that was it. If you need it, you can keep it simple like that. This is the zoom screen that will appear when you enter the exam room. I am only allowed to sit here, and I will be on the screen like this. I have placed this camera somewhere, and on this side is the spinner screen. Of course, I 'll also turn on the camera. I am just giving an example. And the thing is, I just sit here and speak very normally. that is my experience when I took the IELTS Speaking online via Zune last January. I went to Ngoc Khanh beach, and I hope that through this video, you will feel a little more at ease about what to do if you register for the IELTS exam in the future. I am not a fan of IELTS, but I think the most important thing when I passed was to be confident in myself and just go into the exam room and express myself. that is all I need. I wish you all a great exam experience! Bye.

And then I took the exam twice at the age of 15 and got an overall of an eight and then I scored 8.5 at the age of 16.

samples.question: However, this candidate sometimes spoke in a somewhat incomprehensible way, sometimes breaking up due to respiration.
samples.transcript: Do you remember when the teacher described a candidate who only remembered after taking their medicine that "OK," " that backpack," "that is the word for doctor," "both are personal adjectives," "personal water bottle," " maybe," "okay," "okay," "okay," "that is hesitation," and also the praposition there, because of the issue of collagen gel, when the candidate conjugated the verb "size" and suddenly remembered and corrected it immediately, "Yeah," "Hero to find a sport for the countries," "the heart," "Okay," next, the candidate in the 6.0 score group could use "of printers," "connected," and "small cars," but not always the public. The candidates can use quite a few connecting words, however, not always. There are times when they use the same connecting word repeatedly, and they often do not have a large vocabulary. Furthermore, another very important criterion, especially for Cao Như Quỳnh, is the length and duration of the answer. samples.question: That grammar error becomes ingrained and then you go and do an IELTS test or you move to an English-speaking country and then you why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking let us call it Filipino English for many many years and no one has ever said that is an error but when you do the IELTS test again you are moving to an English-speaking country they will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of so for example staff was not that much helpful it should have been the staff were not very helpful or every household in Philippines there is really gardens Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. >> there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subjectverb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So, the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get a band six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences. You would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small just small little errors in most sentences. So you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent but this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall you would be in and around 6.5 or seven overall. Now, for most people, seven is is great for from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you you do not know you you are even making them. It does not affect communication so it is not a huge issue. It it just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

samples.question: Then you say " the first thing that comes to my mind." This is the first idea that popped into your head, right?
samples.transcript: The way you use words is very good, but not entirely accurate. The examiner will take note of this. You tried to use connecting words, but it needs to be more accurate. The correct way would be "the first thing that comes to mind is." Then you continue, and it will be more accurate. You also used "however," which is also good. Using "in my perspective" is not entirely correct. From my perspective, you used the phrase "to be honest," or when you answer "yes" to a yes/no question, instead of just saying "yes," you would say "yes definitely." that is also a very good way to answer. So that is an overview of fluency and grammar. Regarding my pronunciation, my intonation is very good. I use variations in pitch to express my emotions. However, after listening for a while, it still sounds a bit flat. So, I am trying to practice at home to slightly increase the pitch, making it higher and lower. For example, "Oh, I work in marketing and I need to research customer insights," it needs to go higher and lower. Currently, I do that, but the range is a bit low and short. If I increase the pitch, I will reduce it in the exam room. It will sound much better. Okay. And regarding pronunciation, I can clearly hear the words and use linking sounds – that is a plus. For example, I can say "someone who cares about cares about," or " gives me." I can pronounce the third-person singular form of the verb correctly – that is a plus. But I also make some mistakes with word formation. For example... Like " negotiate," I heard you pronounce it differently earlier, I do not remember exactly how, but it should be " negotiate." Then, you mispronounced "purchase" a few times, so it should be " purchase purchase." Okay, the second sound is "-," so the word "decide" should be pronounced "-," not " decided." Okay, pay attention.

samples.question: It should be "She always manages," right?

Then, when you say "when we," you might say " when we shopping," but it should be "when we shop" or "when we go shopping." Or "when we are shopping" would be more appropriate. Then you mentioned another point: "They are convenient to purchase." I forgot the context, but your point was that it is convenient for people to buy something. You need to use a dummy subject, "it is convenient for them to do something." Remember, "convenient for someone to do something" requires the "x" for correct grammar.

Of course, use compound complex language. If you want to get a score over six, you cannot just use simple sentences. You have to join the sentences with conjunctions like and, nor, but, for, so, therefore, since, when, if, however, so on. So, review your conjunctions if you are not sure. So when your language is complex, it also becomes more coherent. when your language is more natural again it is more coherent. when it is more complex it is more natural.
